results.notes: Found in mixed woods, predominantly hemlock/beech, buried deeply in sandy soil along a path. Tallest specimen ~18 cm in height, with a silver/grey cap. Rounded ovate cap appears to have radial lines, somewhat shiny. Crowded cream-colored gills under a persistent white membranous veil. (Veil never dropped in these specimens). Stipe shiny white with some pale reddish fibrils, large friable white volva at base breaking quickly into small pieces upon excavation. Stipe slightly more narrow at apex while widening towards a thick, somewhat pointed base. Stipe solid, stuffed with white material. Unpleasant, vaguely chlorine-like odor.

Part of the true color of the cap is obscured by a dusting of dirt that would not brush off. This species has become my arch nemesis for ID this season. results.notes: Growing under oak, in relatively sandy soil. No immediate bruising present. results.location_name: Uglow Creek, NW of Jordan River, Vancouver Island, British Columbia, Canada

results.notes:
A single fruiting body collected at the NJMA foray by person(s) unknown. The habitat is mostly likely that of mixed hardwoods.
When I was shown this, I thought it was one of the white sect. Vaginatae, owing to the long stipe, lack of a PV, and noticeable marginal striations, and my justification for the pinkish staining on the cap was color transfer from other mushrooms. It dawned on me this could be a sect. Amidella only when I got home and took a look at the spores — they were upper range elongate and cylindric (unmounted at x400)!
The whitish to pale creamy cap featuring pink stains from injury is 5 cm in diameter and 5 mm thick above the stipe; marginal striations are 5-6 mm long (up to 0.24R); the gills are 7 mm wide, pale cream individually and with a pinkish cast en masse when viewed edge-on; short gills are subtruncate to subattenuate, and with both straight and rounded edges; the curved stipe is 14 cm long overall, 5-6 mm wide at its narrowest point and 1 cm wide just above the volval sack, covered with a whitish pulverulence in the upper 1/3 of length, its cross-section having a shallow central canal partially stuffed with some fibrous material, and its context staining pink upon exposure to air; the whitish membranous tubular volva is is 3.5-3.7 cm tall and 100% subterranean.

Basic Microscopy:
Spores were mounted in Melzer’s and measured in the profile view (apiculus to the side).
[20/1/1]: L x W = (8.1-) 8.8~10.9 (-11.9) x (4.7-) 5.1~6.0 (-6.7) μm, L’ x W’ = 10.0 × 5.4 μm; Q = (1.59-) 1.64~2.10 (-2.14), Q’ = 1.85.
Amyloid, upper-range ellipsoid (1 spore) to mostly elongate (16 spores) to cylindric (3 spores); the shape of spores was variable: ranging from cigar-shaped to more ovoid silhouette and rarely pear-shaped, and some even had a suprahilar disc.
The above measurements are in good agreement with RET’s data for A. dolichopus and A. whetstoneae.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 27-May-21):
The first 776 characters of the LSU locus were obtained from Dr. Kudzma from this collection and posted by me here. The sequence is a “joined contig” of a long forward read from the LSU0F primer and short reverse read originating from the LR22 primer. The reads required careful separation of two haplotypes due to a single point of heterogeneity embedded in the ITS4B primer area and continuing all the way to the end of the read. This work was required to get the most out of the traces. Without haplotype resolution, the sequence assembled from the readily legible portions of the reads is only 284 base pairs (bps) long, with a 146 bps common overlap.
A BLASTn-100 search of this sequence gave 9 accession of Amanita whetstoneae published by RET as top hits with 99.6-99.9% similarity.
This collection was supposed to be sampled for ITS and submitted to FunDiS for sequencing in March 2021, but apparently this didn’t happen (records checked on 14-Feb-23).

results.notes:
Five fruiting bodies (in at least two collections) found by unknown participants of the NJMA foray.
The morphological details can be inferred from the pix.
The caps are 4 & 5 cm wide. The stipes are 11.5 and 10 cm long (the smaller-capped fb has a longer stipe) and 6-10 mm wide.
The unmounted spores visualized at x400 appear mostly ellipsoid, with some broadly ellipsoid and low-end elongate spores also present. I now longer have the slides with spore prints; measurements at x1000 will have to be obtained from the two mature basidiomata.

results.notes:
On the bark on an unknown hardwood (?) log. All structures inamyloid. Monomitic with clamped generative hyphae. Hyphidia absent. Cystidia smooth, most tapering and basally swollen with a shape like those of Hyphoderma argillaceum. Some cystidia shaped like the previously mentioned cystidia but with irregular outgrowths and some more cylindrical and with apical incrustation. Cystidia projecting up to 76.9 µm. Cystidia measurements from Piximetre: (39) 43.6 – 76.7 (97.1) × (9) 9.3 – 12.2 (17.7) µm, Q = (2.5) 3.6 – 8.2 (9.6); N = 10, Me = 60.9 × 11.4 µm; Qe = 5.6
Individual cystidia: 76.73 × 9.33 µm, 39.01 × 10.94 µm, 62.46 × 11.13 µm, 52.54 × 12.22 µm, 71.42 × 11.39 µm, 43.63 × 17.69 µm, 53.09 × 9.04 µm, 61.33 × 11.56 µm, 51.71 × 10.13 µm, 97.11 × 10.08 µm
Basidia terminal, clavate and 4-sterigmate. At least one basidium measuring 24.49 × 6.23 µm. Spores smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements from Piximetre: (6.1) 6.7 – 8.2 (8.4) × (3.7) 3.8 – 4.5 (5) µm, Q = (1.5) 1.6 – 1.9 (2.1); N = 25, Me = 7.4 × 4.2 µm; Qe = 1.7
Individual spores: 7.17 × 3.69 µm, 8.23 × 4.98 µm, 6.75 × 4.16 µm, 8.25 × 4.43 µm, 7.29 × 4.44 µm, 7.38 × 4.50 µm, 6.98 × 4.55 µm, 7.77 × 4.32 µm, 6.84 × 4.15 µm, 7.12 × 4.24 µm, 7.61 × 4.30 µm, 8.36 × 4.42 µm, 6.12 × 4.16 µm, 7.02 × 3.86 µm, 7.55 × 4.42 µm, 7.23 × 3.83 µm, 6.75 × 4.31 µm, 8.10 × 4.30 µm, 6.79 × 3.78 µm, 8.44 × 4.15 µm, 6.75 × 4.12 µm, 7.13 × 4.25 µm, 7.57 × 4.25 µm, 7.64 × 3.66 µm, 6.98 × 4.07 µm

results.notes:
Color: White with tan patches
Odor: Coal tar
Taste: not tasted
General Notes
This was found under and around a fallen tree (Elm) where the stump held
the fallen portion about a foot or so from the ground. Under and around
we found the fruiting bodies of what appeared to be Coprinopsis
varigata. The younger fruiting bodies were ovoid in shape, with the
older ones expanding to a dumbbell shape, with the upper part growing
into the cap. It had rained the previous day and the fruiting bodies
were covered with droplets of an amber fluid. Slicing them vertically
showed that the stems were full of water which flowed away quickly,
after which they appeared hollow. The entire mushroom was covered in a
cottony covering, which tore as the cap expanded leaving an annulus.
Any rubbing also revealed a smooth gray surface under the covering. The
odor was unpleasant and smelled lightly of coal-tar. The taste was
indistinguishable.
Pileus
The general color was whitish, with gray undertones. The caps were not
fully mature but were about 2-3 cm in diameter. The flesh was thin,
about 1 mm over the gills.
Lamellae
These were just beginning to deliquesce. They were typical for larger
Coprinus species about 35×6 millimeters.
Stipe
There was a bulbous base. Most of the species did not appear to be fully
mature, but on one the height of the entire body was 7 cm with a stem
width of 12 mm at the base and 10 at the apex.
results.location_name: Fort Ridgely State Park, Nicollet Co., Minnesota, USA

results.notes:

General Notes

The cups were typical of Scutellinia scutellata. About 4 mm to 8 mm in
size, with “eyelashes” on the cup margin. They were reddish-orange.

results.notes:
Color: Whitish Cream
Odor: coal tar
Taste: not tasted
General Notes
These small whitish mushrooms were found growing on twigs and woody
debris. The surrounding woods were all hardwoods – elm, oak, maple. They
seemed to have covered some of the twigs with a white mycelium. They
were infundibuliform in shape. They smelled distinctly of coal tar.
Since we had earlier found a Coprinopsis with a similar smell, we
checked that the smell was not coming from our fingers or elsewhere, but
it indeed seemed to originate with the mushroom. We keyed it out using only macroscopic
features in Graham “Mushrooms of the Great Lakes Region” to Clitocybe
adirondackensis (now Singerocybe adirondackensis). We compared our
specimen with descriptions in Baroni “Mushrooms of the Northeastern
United States and Eastern Canada” of S. adirondackensis and related
species and found it a good fit based on macroscopic features.
Cap
The surface of the cap was silky smooth. The size range was 13-23 mm in
diameter. There were no veil remnants and the margin of the cap was
smooth.
Lamellae
These were close to subdistant, decurrently attached. There were a few
tapering lamellulae present. There were no signs of cystidia.
Stipe
This was colored the same as the cap and gills. The entire mushroom was
15 mm tall and the stipe diameter was about 3 mm.
results.location_name: Fort Ridgely State Park, Nicollet Co., Minnesota, USA

results.notes:
Color: gray
Odor: Strongly of garlic and somewhat like Entoloma abortivum
Taste: did not taste
General Notes
This appeared directly to be a small Entoloma. The total height of each
was about 15 mm and the cap width was also 15 mm. One of them was a
double mushroom with two caps crowding each other with the stipes
touching at the base. The most distinctive thing was the strong smell of
garlic. Each time that we opened the collecting case, it was very strong
from 2-3 feet away. We could not find any North American Entolomas with
a garlic smell. I checked the spores which were angular, mostly 6-sided,
10-11×8 microns. The spores are clearly pink from the cast to the gills
(seen in the photos). So we left it at that.
Pileus
About 15mm in diameter. Appeared whitish at first, then somewhat light
gray.
Lamellae
The gill attachment is decurrent. There appears to be 3 levels of
lamellulae as seen in the photos.
Stipe
The total height of the fruiting body was 15mm. The stipe had white
mycelium at the base.

results.notes:
Color: Whitish cap
Odor: none detected
Taste: did not taste
General Notes
This fungus appeared to be growing on a large diameter living
white oak. It appeared gregarious over an area about 2 feet in
height and a foot wide about 4-5 feet from the base of the tree.
It had gills and a cap, but appeared to be growing sessile without
much of a stipe, but it was attached more or less centrally and
had a floppy appearance with the gills seeming to face upward
in places. The flesh was thin and had a dried appearance. It had
brown spores, which were oval 5-6×4-4.5 microns. I feel somewhat
confident calling it a Crepidotus – maybe?
Pileus
White with a smooth, slightly felty surface. The largest caps were about
15 mm in diameter. Most caps were convoluted and broken.
Lamellae
The gills were a light clay brown, somewhat close and irregular-wavy.
Stipe
Only about 1-2 mm in length. There appeared to be a little white
tomentum at the base.

results.notes:
A mushroom club member brought these along to a foray to be IDed. They were found growing in moss. I was quite certain they represented a species of Cudonia (except the habitat seemed to not fit)… until I scoped the spores: septate with 5-7 septa, ellipsoid to subfusiform, some curved into a crescent shape, 18-21 × 4.5-6.5.

I think these fruit bodies dried out after having been harvested. This may account for the caps lacking viscosity and the stipes being compressed.

results.notes: Found (usually in the same location every season) near a dry stream bed with rich dark rocky soil under sycamore, elm and walnut trees in my area. The bigger yellow morels I find like to grow in very thick underbrush near sycamore trees in very heavy leaf litter with a lot of shade and moist, rich, rocky soil. They also seem to like burn areas, as my morel “hotspot” had a bad forest fire about 3 years ago and there are more and more every season in this location. Very strong smell, amazing flavor!! I can usually smell these before I even see them with my eyes.

results.notes: On the underside of a hardwood log with several corticiaceous fungi, including a Tomentella species. Betula sp., Acer sp., Fagus grandifolia and Tsuga canadensis were present in the general area. Monomitic with simple-septate generative hyphae. Some hyphae swollen and with non-septate branching. Tetrahedral crystals abundant along the spines. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores smooth, thin-walled and weakly amyloid. Amyloid detritus present in the hymenium. Spore measurements: (3.2) 3.3 – 4.9 (5.2) × (1.9) 2 – 2.6 (2.8) µm, Q = (1.4) 1.5 – 1.9 (2.1); N = 30, Me = 4 × 2.3 µm; Qe = 1.7

results.notes:
This is the first time a Craterellus has been seen at the Cuajimoloyas fair.

After some debate the local authorities gave us permission to bring it home to study.

Seen on the display table, but was probably found under oak.

Physically it was in poor condition, but it was hoped that it could be identified with DNA analysis. After the first PCR reaction failed with ITS1F/ITS4 primers, two new DNA extracts were made and PCR was performed with the primer pairs ITSU1/ITSU4, LR0R/LR5, ITS1F/ITS4B and ITS1F/ITS4b-truncated, ITS1/ITS2 and ITS3/ITS4. After a total of 13 PCR reactions were attempted and none were successful, it was determined that the DNA was too degraded to analyze, likely due to bacterial decomposition. A fresh collection will be needed to unravel the mystery of which Craterellus species occurs in Cuajimoloyas.
results.location_name: Cuajimoloyas, Oaxaca, Mexico

When I read the range of spore lengths for variipes provided in NAB, my first reaction was that this mushroom must be something other than variipes. NAB says 12-18 × 4-6; this specimen 9-13 × 4-5. But, Mushroom Expert says 9-16 (18) x 4-6. So the spores fall within the range provided by Mushroom Expert. I wonder why there is such a discrepancy in reported spore dimensions? results.notes:
No analysis performed on these. But appearance and location matches multiple rooseveltensis collections I have made over the past 12 years.

Large one is almost certainly associated with a mature shagbark hickory tree. Smaller one is located maybe 30-40 feet from the large one; smallish oaks also in this area.

Fruiting during period of very wet weather.
results.location_name: Property at 239 Golf Course Rd., Hunlock Twp., Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
Growing in a different location than obs 324324, but I have collected what I believe to be A. rooseveltensis form this spot on my property. Spore morphology for this collection is in line with rooseveltensis, as is the buried basal volva that is difficult to extract intact but does not disintegrate. The aspect that differs from my current understanding of A. rooseveltensis is the dark color seen on the cap (photos are accurate in this respect). The area includes several types of trees, but shagbark hickory seems to be the only reasonable associate for these mushrooms. (Maple, ash, black walnut also present.)

So, this is interesting because it represents a potential broadening of the rooseveltensis concept.

Fruited during period of very wet weather.
results.location_name: Property at 239 Golf Course Rd., Hunlock Twp., Pennsylvania, USA

notes_fields.Chemical_Reactions: Chemicals absorbed by substrate, could not determine reactions
notes_fields.Macroscopic_Features: Strange, yellowish odontoid to hydnoid “crust”; appears to be teeth on wood without a subiculum, shiny when moved in the light; aculei practically microscopic, gregarious, length (166) 182-279 (307) µm, width (38) 45-76 (91) µm (i.e., about .2-.3 mm x .05-.1 mm)
notes_fields.Microscopic_Features: Subglobose to ellipsoid spores, length (2.7) 2.9-4.0 (4.4) x width (2.2) 2.4-3.0 (3.2) µm, Q (1.1) 1.2-1.5 (1.5); basidia with 4 sterigmata, rectangular crystals abundant on the surface of the aculei, clamp connections present

results.notes:
Mucronella sp. is the best determination I have for this, confounded only by the fact that these spores were inamyloid in Melzer’s reagent, not amyloid. Mucronella calva and Mucronella flava generally fit except these spores were shorter in length than what is reported for these two species. They more closely match M. flava (3.5-5.5) than M. calva (4-6), except the fruiting body was not as bright yellow-orange as most M. flava specimens are depicted.

—

Thick, tannish, smooth and bumpy, cracked, effused, resupinate, determinate margin; the sporocarp is growing over moss, the moss is kind of embedded within the trama; the hymenium is hydrophobic, slowly absorbing liquids; 5% KOH turns the hymenium greyish blue, ammonium absorbs more quickly and dissolves tissue, turning the leftover tissue very slightly greyish blue; odor kind of nice and mushroomy, taste not determined.

notes_fields.Host: Acer x freemanii (columnar freeman maple #68010), same as UWMA0086

results.notes:
I thought this was the same species as UWMA0086, just on a different branch, however back at the bench I saw that the texture is way different, more odontioid; there were small black apothecia embedded within the crust, usually with their edge flush with the surface of the hymenium, designated as UWMA0089; the hymenium of the crust was hydrophoboic, not readily absorbing 10% KOH which turned yellowish over time sitting as a drop on the hymenium, ammonium absorbing eventually and darkening the hymenium.

notes_fields.Comments: see this species list for more observations of this fungus (or group of fungi), whose identity has evaded me for upwards of six years. in each example, the yellow stipe tissue turns deep purple in the presence of KOH. excited to not only to have a collection for sequencing and culturing, but for have received the provisional ID of Lindquistia — a xylariaceous anamorph — courtesy of IMA president, Dr. Keith Seifert, who I showed this to at the recent IMC in Puerto Rico. Dr. Seifert also possesses a portion of the collection, and I am working on gathering together more material from around the world.

results.notes:
This Find was most unusual as Amanita Muscaria usually only display in Late April. ( Farm land at Comboyne Plateau){Boorganna Nature Reserve
This small, 396 ha reserve is the second-oldest nature reserve in the state. It is a rare opportunity to see what the plateau was like before the cedar cutters and dairy farmers cleared the forests. It is located by heading west out of town on the Comboyne Road, turning right into Colling Road and and following the signs to Boorganna Nature Reserve and Rawson Falls. There is a 2.7 km walking track that leads through remnant rainforest to a lookout at the 40 m high Rawson Falls. There is a brochure available at the Comboyne Community Centre. The reserve possesses sub-tropical and eucalypt forest, diverse birdlife and fauna and there are excellent picnic areas. In spring it is noted for its flowering orange blossom and spotted cinnamon orchids. For further information check out http://www.nationalparks.nsw.gov.au/....}
A full field in this new find here were on display in early Winter. (Au season)??? I chose to show young & mature fungi in this new area at Wauchope upload.

results.notes:
Extremely small, white coprinoid growing from palm material.
Measurements:
Button: 2mm diameter by 3mm height
Expanded specimen: 3mm cap diameter by 5mm height.
Stipe length, ~ 7mm (1mm inserted into cap). Stipe width, 1mm.
Grayish-brown floccules on pileus of both specimens.
This coprinoid is very common growing from palm fronds/sheaths/fibers and also from felled palm bases. It can often be seen in its white button stage alongside specimens that have already fully expanded and deliquesced. It is attached on the surface of the substrate with a small, white disk at the base of the stipe. See also MO#315362 .

—

results.notes: Growing in edge of pine needle duff and grassy lawn; below pine. Cap with minute fibers; white with splotches of yellow. Veil remnants present at margin. Spores 4.5-5 × 3-4; smooth and slightly ellipsoid, dextrinoid.

results.notes:
These specimens were found approximately 100m into a mineshaft. Each cluster sprouts from a single moth, which appears to have frozen in place on the rock ceiling, in the same manner as insects compelled by cordyceps. About 8-9 moth-clusters inside of a 1 sq.m area at the end of the longest tunnel; none others observed.
Return visit planned in near future to inspect more closely and obtain samples.
